children.value: The baseline problem which I will use to demonstrate the Sequential Endogenous Grid Method (
) is a discrete time version of

where a consumer has the ability to adjust their labor as well as their consumption in response to financial risk. The objective consists of maximizing the present discounted lifetime utility of consumption and leisure.

children.html: V0(B0,θ0)=max⁡Et[∑n=0T−tβnu(Ct+n,Zt+n)]\VFunc_0(\BLev_0, \tShkEmp_0) = \max \Ex_{t} \left[ \sum_{n = 0}^{T-t} \DiscFac^{n} \utilFunc(\CLev_{t+n}, \Leisure_{t+n}) \right]V0​(B0​,θ0​)=maxEt​[n=0∑T−t​βnu(Ct+n​,Zt+n​)]

children.value: In particular, this example makes use of a utility function that is based on Example 1 in the paper, which is that of additively separable utility of labor and leisure as

children.html: u(C,Z)=u(C)+h(Z)=C1−ρ1−ρ+ν1−ρZ1−ζ1−ζ\utilFunc(\CLev, \Leisure) = \util(\CLev) + \h(\Leisure) = \frac{C^{1-\CRRA}}{1-\CRRA} + \labShare^{1-\CRRA} \frac{\Leisure^{1-\leiShare}}{1-\leiShare}u(C,Z)=u(C)+h(Z)=1−ρC1−ρ​+ν1−ρ1−ζZ1−ζ​
ν1−ρ\labShare^{1-\CRRA}ν1−ρ

children.value: is introduced to allow for a balanced growth path as in
. The use of additively separable utility is ad-hoc, as it will allow for the use of multiple
steps in the solution process, as we’ll see later.
This model represents a consumer who begins the period with a level of bank balances

children.html: bt\bRat_{t}bt​
θt\tShkEmp_{t}θt​

children.value: . Simultaneously, they are able to choose consumption, labor intensity, and a risky portfolio share with the objective of maximizing their utility of consumption and leisure, as well as their future wealth.
The problem can be written in normalized recursive form

children.html: vt(bt,θt)=max⁡{ct,zt,ςt}u(ct,zt)+βEt[Γt+11−ρvt+1(bt+1,θt+1)]s.t.ℓt=1−ztmt=bt+θtℓtat=mt−ctRt+1=R+(Rt+1−R)ςtbt+1=atRt+1/Γt+1\begin{split} \vFunc_{t}(\bRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) & = \max_{\{\cRat_{t}, \leisure_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}\}} \utilFunc(\cRat_{t}, \leisure_{t}) + \DiscFac \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{1-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1} (\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}) \right] \\ & \text{s.t.} \\ \labor_{t} & = 1 - \leisure_{t} \\ \mRat_{t} & = \bRat_{t} + \tShkEmp_{t}\labor_{t} \\ \aRat_{t} & = \mRat_{t} - \cRat_{t} \\ \Rport_{t+1} & = \Rfree + (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \riskyshare_{t} \\ \bRat_{t+1} & = \aRat_{t} \Rport_{t+1} / \PGro_{t+1} \end{split}vt​(bt​,θt​)ℓt​mt​at​Rt+1​bt+1​​={ct​,zt​,ςt​}max​u(ct​,zt​)+βEt​[Γt+11−ρ​vt+1​(bt+1​,θt+1​)]s.t.=1−zt​=bt​+θt​ℓt​=mt​−ct​=R+(Rt+1​−R)ςt​=at​Rt+1​/Γt+1​​
ℓt\labor_{t}ℓt​

children.value: is the market resources totaling bank balances and labor income,

children.html: at\aRat_{t}at​

children.value: We can make a few choices to create a sequential problem which will allow us to use multiple

steps in succession. First, the agent decides their labor-leisure trade-off and receives a wage. Their wage plus their previous bank balance then becomes their market resources. Second, given market resources, the agent makes a pure consumption-saving decision. Finally, given an amount of savings, the consumer then decides their risky portfolio share.
Starting from the beginning of the period, we can define the labor-leisure problem as

children.html: vt(bt,θt)=max⁡zth(zt)+v~t(mt)s.t.0≤zt≤1ℓt=1−ztmt=bt+θtℓt.\begin{split} \vFunc_{t}(\bRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) & = \max_{ \leisure_{t}} \h(\leisure_{t}) + \vOpt_{t} (\mRat_{t}) \\ & \text{s.t.} \\ 0 & \leq \leisure_{t} \leq 1 \\ \labor_{t} & = 1 - \leisure_{t} \\ \mRat_{t} & = \bRat_{t} + \tShkEmp_{t}\labor_{t}. \end{split}vt​(bt​,θt​)0ℓt​mt​​=zt​max​h(zt​)+v~t​(mt​)s.t.≤zt​≤1=1−zt​=bt​+θt​ℓt​.​

children.value: The pure consumption-saving problem is then

children.html: v~t(mt)=max⁡ctu(ct)+βvt(at)s.t.0≤ct≤mtat=mt−ct.\begin{split} \vOpt_{t}(\mRat_{t}) & = \max_{\cRat_{t}} \util(\cRat_{t}) + \DiscFac\vEnd_{t}(\aRat_{t}) \\ & \text{s.t.} \\ 0 & \leq \cRat_{t} \leq \mRat_{t} \\ \aRat_{t} & = \mRat_{t} - \cRat_{t}. \end{split}v~t​(mt​)0at​​=ct​max​u(ct​)+βvt​(at​)s.t.≤ct​≤mt​=mt​−ct​.​

children.value: Finally, the risky portfolio problem is

children.html: vt(at)=max⁡ςtEt[Γt+11−ρvt+1(bt+1,θt+1)]s.t.0≤ςt≤1Rt+1=R+(Rt+1−R)ςtbt+1=atRt+1/Γt+1.\begin{split} \vEnd_{t}(\aRat_{t}) & = \max_{\riskyshare_{t}} \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{1-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}) \right] \\ & \text{s.t.} \\ 0 & \leq \riskyshare_{t} \leq 1 \\ \Rport_{t+1} & = \Rfree + (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \riskyshare_{t} \\ \bRat_{t+1} & = \aRat_{t} \Rport_{t+1} / \PGro_{t+1}. \end{split}vt​(at​)0Rt+1​bt+1​​=ςt​max​Et​[Γt+11−ρ​vt+1​(bt+1​,θt+1​)]s.t.≤ςt​≤1=R+(Rt+1​−R)ςt​=at​Rt+1​/Γt+1​.​

children.value: This sequential approach is explicitly modeled after the nested approaches explored in

. However, I will offer additional insights that expand on these methods. An important observation is that now, every single choice is self-contained in a subproblem, and although the structure is specifically chosen to minimize the number of state variables at every stage, the problem does not change by this structural imposition. This is because there is no additional information or realization of uncertainty that happens between decisions, as can be seen by the expectation operator being in the last subproblem. From the perspective of the consumer, these decisions are essentially simultaneous, but a careful organization into sub-period problems enables us to solve the model more efficiently and can provide key economic insights. In this problem, as we will see, a key insight will be the ability to explicitly calculate the marginal value of wealth and the Frisch elasticity of labor.
As useful as it is to be able to use the
step more than once, there are clear problems where the
step is not applicable. This basic labor-portfolio choice problem demonstrates where we can use an additional
step, and where we can not. First, we go over a subproblem where we can not use the

In reorganizing the labor-portfolio problem into subproblems, we assigned the utility of leisure to the leisure-labor subproblem and the utility of consumption to the consumption-savings subproblem. There are no more separable convex utility functions to assign to this problem, and even if we re-organized the problem in a way that moved one of the utility functions into this subproblem, they would not be useful in solving this subproblem via

as there is no direct relation between the risky share of portfolio and consumption or leisure. Therefore, the only way to solve this subproblem is through standard convex optimization and root-finding techniques.
Restating the problem in compact form gives

children.html: vt(at)=max⁡ςtEt[Γt+11−ρvt+1(at(R+(Rt+1−R)ςt),θt+1)].\vEnd_{t}(\aRat_{t}) = \max_{\riskyshare_{t}} \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{1-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}\left(\aRat_{t}(\Rfree + (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \riskyshare_{t}), \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) \right].vt​(at​)=ςt​max​Et​[Γt+11−ρ​vt+1​(at​(R+(Rt+1​−R)ςt​),θt+1​)].

children.value: The first-order condition with respect to the risky portfolio share is then

children.html: Et[Γt+1−ρvt+1b(bt+1,θt+1)(Rt+1−R)]=0.\Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}^{\bRat}\left(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \right] = 0.Et​[Γt+1−ρ​vt+1b​(bt+1​,θt+1​)(Rt+1​−R)]=0.

children.value: Finding the optimal risky share requires numerical optimization and root-solving of the first-order condition. To close out the problem, we can calculate the envelope condition as

children.html: vt′(at)=Et[Γt+1−ρvt+1b(bt+1,θt+1)Rt+1].\vEnd_{t}'(\aRat_{t}) = \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}^{\bRat}\left(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) \Rport_{t+1} \right].vt′​(at​)=Et​[Γt+1−ρ​vt+1b​(bt+1​,θt+1​)Rt+1​].

children.value: A note on avoiding taking expectations more than once

children.label: A note on avoiding taking expectations more than once

children.value: We could instead define the portfolio choice subproblem as:

children.html: vt(at)=max⁡ςtv~ˋ(at,ςt)\vEnd_{t}(\aRat_{t}) = \max_{\riskyshare_{t}} \vOptAlt(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t})vt​(at​)=ςt​max​v~ˋ(at​,ςt​)

v~ˋt(at,ςt)=Et[Γt+11−ρvt+1(bt+1,θt+1)]Rt+1=R+(Rt+1−R)ςtbt+1=atRt+1/Γt+1\begin{split} \vOptAlt_{t}(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}) & = \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{1-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}\left(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) \right] \\ \Rport_{t+1} & = \Rfree + (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \riskyshare_{t} \\ \bRat_{t+1} & = \aRat_{t} \Rport_{t+1} / \PGro_{t+1} \end{split}v~ˋt​(at​,ςt​)Rt+1​bt+1​​=Et​[Γt+11−ρ​vt+1​(bt+1​,θt+1​)]=R+(Rt+1​−R)ςt​=at​Rt+1​/Γt+1​​

children.value: In this case, the process is similar. The only difference is that we don’t have to take expectations more than once. Given the next period’s solution, we can calculate the marginal value functions as:

children.html: v~ˋta(at,ςt)=Et[Γt+1−ρvt+1′(bt+1,θt+1)Rt+1]v~ˋtς(at,ςt)=Et[Γt+1−ρvt+1′(bt+1,θt+1)at(Rt+1−R)]\begin{split} \vOptAlt_{t}^{\aRat}(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}) & = \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}'\left(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) \Rport_{t+1} \right] \\ \vOptAlt_{t}^{\riskyshare}(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}) & = \Ex_{t} \left[ \PGro_{t+1}^{-\CRRA} \vFunc_{t+1}'\left(\bRat_{t+1}, \tShkEmp_{t+1}\right) \aRat_{t} (\Risky_{t+1} - \Rfree) \right] \\ \end{split}v~ˋta​(at​,ςt​)v~ˋtς​(at​,ςt​)​=Et​[Γt+1−ρ​vt+1′​(bt+1​,θt+1​)Rt+1​]=Et​[Γt+1−ρ​vt+1′​(bt+1​,θt+1​)at​(Rt+1​−R)]​

children.value: If we are clever, we can calculate both of these in one step. Now, the optimal risky share can be found by the first-order condition and we can use it to evaluate the envelope condition.

children.html: F.O.C.:v~ˋtς(at,ςt∗)=0E.C.:vta(at)=v~ˋta(at,ςt∗)\text{F.O.C.:} \qquad \vOptAlt_{t}^{\riskyshare}(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}^{*}) = 0 \qquad \text{E.C.:} \qquad \vEnd_{t}^{\aRat}(\aRat_{t}) = \vOptAlt_{t}^{\aRat}(\aRat_{t}, \riskyshare_{t}^{*})F.O.C.:v~ˋtς​(at​,ςt∗​)=0E.C.:vta​(at​)=v~ˋta​(at​,ςt∗​)

children.value: but I will cover it for exposition. We can begin the solution process by restating the consumption-savings subproblem in a more compact form, substituting the market resources constraint and ignoring the no-borrowing constraint for now. The problem is:

children.html: v~t(mt)=max⁡ctu(ct)+βvt(mt−ct)\vOpt_{t}(\mRat_{t}) = \max_{\cRat_{t}} \util(\cRat_{t}) + \DiscFac \vEnd_{t}(\mRat_{t}-\cRat_{t})v~t​(mt​)=ct​max​u(ct​)+βvt​(mt​−ct​)

children.value: To solve, we derive the first-order condition with respect to

children.html: ct\cRat_{t}ct​

children.value: which gives the familiar Euler equation:

children.html: u′(ct)=βvt′(mt−ct)=βvt′(at)\utilFunc'(\cRat_t) = \DiscFac \vEnd_{t}'(\mRat_{t} - \cRat_{t}) = \DiscFac \vEnd_{t}'(\aRat_{t})u′(ct​)=βvt′​(mt​−ct​)=βvt′​(at​)

children.value: Inverting the above equation is the (first)

children.html: ct(at)=u′−1(βvt′(at))\cEndFunc_{t}(\aRat_{t}) = \utilFunc'^{-1}\left( \DiscFac \vEnd_{t}'(\aRat_{t}) \right)ct​(at​)=u′−1(βvt′​(at​))

children.value: Given the utility function above, the marginal utility of consumption and its inverse are

children.html: u′(c)=c−ρu′−1(x)=x−1/ρ.\utilFunc'(\cRat) = \cRat^{-\CRRA} \qquad \utilFunc'^{-1}(\xRat) = \xRat^{-1/\CRRA}.u′(c)=c−ρu′−1(x)=x−1/ρ.

children.html: ct([a])\cEndFunc_{t}(\aMat)ct​([a])

children.value: that optimizes the consumption-saving problem, since the first-order condition is necessary and sufficient. Further, using the market resources constraint, we can recover the exact amount of market resources that is consistent with this consumption-saving decision as

children.html: mt([a])=ct([a])+[a].\mEndFunc_{t}(\aMat) = \cEndFunc_{t}(\aMat) + \aMat.mt​([a])=ct​([a])+[a].
mt([a])\mEndFunc_{t}(\aMat)mt​([a])

The envelope condition will be useful in the next section, but for completeness is defined here.

children.html: v~t′(mt)=βvt′(at)=u′(ct)\vOpt_{t}'(\mRat_{t}) = \DiscFac \vEnd_{t}'(\aRat_{t}) = \utilFunc'(\cRat_{t})v~t′​(mt​)=βvt′​(at​)=u′(ct​)

children.value: The labor-leisure subproblem can be restated more compactly as:

children.html: vt(bt,θt)=max⁡zth(zt)+v~t(bt+θt(1−zt))\vFunc_{t}(\bRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) = \max_{ \leisure_{t}} \h(\leisure_{t}) + \vOpt_{t}(\bRat_{t} + \tShkEmp_{t}(1-\leisure_{t}))vt​(bt​,θt​)=zt​max​h(zt​)+v~t​(bt​+θt​(1−zt​))

children.value: The first-order condition with respect to leisure implies the labor-leisure Euler equation

children.html: h′(zt)=v~t′(mt)θt\h'(\leisure_{t}) = \vOpt_{t}'(\mRat_{t}) \tShkEmp_{t}h′(zt​)=v~t′​(mt​)θt​

children.value: The marginal utility of leisure and its inverse are

children.html: h′(z)=νz−ζh′−1(x)=(x/ν)−1/ζ\h'(\leisure) = \labShare\leisure^{-\leiShare} \qquad \h'^{-1}(\xRat) = (\xRat/\labShare)^{-1/\leiShare}h′(z)=νz−ζh′−1(x)=(x/ν)−1/ζ
[m]\mMat[m]
[θ]\tShkMat[θ]
zt([m],[θ])=h′−1(v~t′([m])[θ])\zEndFunc_{t}(\mMat, \tShkMat) = \h'^{-1}\left( \vOpt_{t}'(\mMat) \tShkMat \right)zt​([m],[θ])=h′−1(v~t′​([m])[θ])

children.value: In this case, it’s important to note that there are conditions for leisure itself. An agent with a small level of market resources

children.html: mt\mRat_{t}mt​

children.value: might want to work more than their available time endowment, especially at higher levels of income

children.html: θt\tShkEmp_{t}θt​

children.value: , if the utility of leisure is not enough to compensate for their low wealth. In these situations, the optimal unconstrained leisure might be negative, so we must impose a constraint on the optimal leisure function. This is similar to the treatment of an artificial borrowing constraint in the pure consumption subproblem. From now on, let’s call this constrained optimal function

children.html: z^t([m],[θ])\hat{\zEndFunc}_{t}(\mMat, \tShkMat)z^​t​([m],[θ])
z^t([m],[θ])=max⁡[min⁡[zt([m],[θ]),1],0]\hat{\zEndFunc}_{t}(\mMat, \tShkMat) = \max \left[ \min \left[ \zEndFunc_{t}(\mMat, \tShkMat), 1 \right], 0 \right]z^​t​([m],[θ])=max[min[zt​([m],[θ]),1],0]
lt(mt,θt)=1−z^t(mt,θt)\lEndFunc_{t}(\mRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) = 1 - \hat{\zEndFunc}_{t}(\mRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t})lt​(mt​,θt​)=1−z^​t​(mt​,θt​)
θt\tShkEmp_{t}θt​

children.value: as an exogenous grid, we can find the endogenous grid of bank balances as

children.html: bt(mt,θt)=mt−θtlt(mt,θt)\bEndFunc_{t}(\mRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) = \mRat_{t} - \tShkEmp_{t}\lEndFunc_{t}(\mRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t})bt​(mt​,θt​)=mt​−θt​lt​(mt​,θt​)

children.value: The envelope condition then provides a heterogeneous Frisch elasticity of labor as simply

children.html: vtb(bt,θt)=v~t′(mt)=h′(zt)/θt.\vFunc_{t}^{b}(\bRat_{t}, \tShkEmp_{t}) = \vOpt_{t}'(\mRat_{t}) = \h'(\leisure_{t})/\tShkEmp_{t}.vtb​(bt​,θt​)=v~t′​(mt​)=h′(zt​)/θt​.

children.value: An alternative formulation for the utility of leisure is to state it in terms of the disutility of labor as in (references)

children.html: h(ℓ)=−ζℓ1+ν1+ν\h(\labor) = - \leiShare \frac{\labor^{1+\labShare}}{1+\labShare}h(ℓ)=−ζ1+νℓ1+ν​

children.value: In this case, we can restate the problem as

children.html: h(z)=−ζ(1−z)1+ν1+ν\h(\leisure) = - \leiShare \frac{(1-\leisure)^{1+\labShare}}{1+\labShare}h(z)=−ζ1+ν(1−z)1+ν​

children.value: The marginal utility of leisure and its inverse are

children.html: h′(z)=ζ(1−z)νh′−1(x)=1−(x/ζ)1/ν\h'(\leisure) = \leiShare(1-\leisure)^{\labShare} \qquad \h'^{-1}(\xRat) = 1 - (\xRat/\leiShare)^{1/\labShare}h′(z)=ζ(1−z)νh′−1(x)=1−(x/ζ)1/ν

children.value: seems to be a simple approach, there is one important caveat that we have not discussed, which is the details of the interpolation. In the pure consumption-savings problem, a one-dimensional exogenous grid of post-decision liquid assets

children.html: [a]\aMat[a]

children.value: results in a one-dimensional endogenous grid of total market resources

children.html: [m]\mMat[m]

children.value: . However, as we know from standard

children.html: [m]\mMat[m]

children.value: grid is different from the spacing in the

children.html: [a]\aMat[a]

children.value: grid as the inverted Euler equation is non-linear. This is no problem in a one-dimensional problem as we can simply use non-uniform linear interpolation.

However, the same is true of higher dimensional problems, where the exogenous grid gets mapped to a warped endogenous grid. In this case, it is not possible to use standard multi-linear interpolation, as the resulting endogenous grid is not rectilinear. Instead, I introduce a novel approach to interpolation that I call Warped Grid Interpolation (WGI), which is similar to
’s approach but computationally more efficient and robust. The details of this interpolation method will be further explained in
, but for now, we show the resulting warped endogenous grid for the labor-leisure problem.

children.alt: Warped Curvlinear Grid that results from multivariate EGM. This grid can be interpolated by WGI.

children.value: Warped Curvlinear Grid that results from multivariate
. This grid can be interpolated by WGI.
Assume we have a set of points indexed by

children.html: (i,j)(i,j)(i,j)

children.value: in two-dimensional space for which we have corresponding functional values in a third dimension, such that

children.html: f(xij,yij)=zijf(x_{ij},y_{ij}) = z_{ij}f(xij​,yij​)=zij​

children.value: . In practice, we are interested in cases where the

children.html: zijz_{ij}zij​
f(xij,yij)f(x_{ij},y_{ij})f(xij​,yij​)

children.value: is unknown, so we are unable to compute them at other values of

children.html: xxx
yyy

children.value: --- which is why we want to interpolate

children.html: (xij,yij)(x_{ij},y_{ij})(xij​,yij​)

children.value: points however are not evenly spaced and do not form a rectilinear grid which would make it easy to interpolate the function off the grid. Nevertheless, these points do have a regular structure as we will see.

children.alt: True function and curvilinear grid of points for which we know the value of the function.

children.value: True function and curvilinear grid of points for which we know the value of the function.

, we can see the true function in three-dimensional space, along with the points for which we actually know the value of the function. The underlying regular structure comes from the points’ position in the matrix, the

children.html: (i,j)(i,j)(i,j)

children.value: coordinates. If we join the points along every row and every column, we can see that the resulting grid is regular and piecewise affine (curvilinear).
we see the values of the function at their index coordinate points in the matrix. We can see that there exists a mapping between the curvilinear grid and the index coordinates of the matrix.

children.alt: Homotopy between the curvilinear grid and the index coordinates of the matrix.

children.value: Homotopy between the curvilinear grid and the index coordinates of the matrix.

The objective is to be able to interpolate the value of the function at any point off the grid, where presumably we are only interested in points internal to the curvilinear space and not outside the boundaries. For example, we can imagine that we want an approximation to the function at the point

children.html: (x,y)=(3,5)(x,y) = (3, 5)(x,y)=(3,5)

children.value: . If we could find the corresponding point in the coordinate grid, interpolation would be straightforward. We can find where the

children.html: xxx

children.value: -coordinate of the point of interest intersects with the index-coordinates of the matrix. This is similar to assuming that we have 3 linear interpolators formed by connecting the points on the green lines in the x-direction, and for each interpolator we can approximate the corresponding y and z values using the grid data. Now, for each circle in

children.html: (y,z)(y,z)(y,z)

children.value: , and we can interpolate in the y-direction to find the corresponding z-value for the point’s y-coordinate

children.alt: The method consist of extending the loci of points in the x dimension to find the corresponding crossing points in the y dimension.

children.value: The method consist of extending the loci of points in the

children.html: xxx

children.value: dimension to find the corresponding crossing points in the

children.html: yyy
